dependencies.description:
GNU Make is a tool which controls the generation of executables and
other non-source files of a program from the program's source files.
dependencies.name: gmake

dependencies.description:
Perl 5 is a highly capable, feature-rich programming language with over
27 years of development.
dependencies.name: perl

dependencies.description: Clone - recursively copy Perl datatypes
dependencies.name: perl-clone

dependencies.description: Structured Tags datastructures
dependencies.name: perl-data-stag

dependencies.description:
DB_File is a module which allows Perl programs to make use of the
facilities provided by Berkeley DB version 1.x (if you have a newer
version of DB, see "Using DB_File with Berkeley DB version 2 or
greater"). It is assumed that you have a copy of the Berkeley DB manual
pages at hand when reading this documentation. The interface defined
here mirrors the Berkeley DB interface closely.
dependencies.name: perl-db-file

dependencies.description: MySQL driver for the Perl5 Database Interface (DBI)
dependencies.name: perl-dbd-mysql

dependencies.description:
DBD::Pg is a Perl module that works with the DBI module to provide
access to PostgreSQL databases.
dependencies.name: perl-dbd-pg

dependencies.description: DBD::SQLite - Self-contained RDBMS in a DBI Driver
dependencies.name: perl-dbd-sqlite

dependencies.description:
The DBI is the standard database interface module for Perl. It defines a
set of methods, variables and conventions that provide a consistent
database interface independent of the actual database being used.
dependencies.name: perl-dbi

dependencies.description:
The Error package provides two interfaces. Firstly Error provides a
procedural interface to exception handling. Secondly Error is a base
class for errors/exceptions that can either be thrown, for subsequent
catch, or can simply be recorded.
dependencies.name: perl-error

dependencies.description: Interface to Gd Graphics Library
dependencies.name: perl-gd

dependencies.description: Graph data structures and algorithms
dependencies.name: perl-graph

dependencies.description: Interface to AT&T's GraphViz. Deprecated. See GraphViz2
dependencies.name: perl-graphviz

dependencies.description: HTTP style message (base class)
dependencies.name: perl-http-message

dependencies.description: Emulate file interface for in-core strings
dependencies.name: perl-io-string

dependencies.description:
This toolkit primarily provides modules for performing both traditional
and object-oriented i/o) on things other than normal filehandles; in
particular, IO::Scalar, IO::ScalarArray, and IO::Lines. In the more-
traditional IO::Handle front, we have IO::AtomicFile which may be used
to painlessly create files which are updated atomically. And in the
"this-may-prove-useful" corner, we have IO::Wrap, whose exported
wraphandle() function will clothe anything that's not a blessed object
in an IO::Handle-like wrapper... so you can just use OO syntax and stop
worrying about whether your function's caller handed you a string, a
globref, or a FileHandle.
dependencies.name: perl-io-stringy

dependencies.description:
IPC::Run allows you to run and interact with child processes using
files, pipes, and pseudo-ttys. Both system()-style and scripted usages
are supported and may be mixed. Likewise, functional and OO API styles
are both supported and may be mixed.
dependencies.name: perl-ipc-run

dependencies.description:
The libwww-perl collection is a set of Perl modules which provides a
simple and consistent application programming interface to the World-
Wide Web. The main focus of the library is to provide classes and
functions that allow you to write WWW clients.
dependencies.name: perl-libwww-perl

dependencies.description:
libxml-perl is a collection of smaller Perl modules, scripts, and
documents for working with XML in Perl. libxml-perl software works in
combination with XML::Parser, PerlSAX, XML::DOM, XML::Grove and others.
dependencies.name: perl-libxml-perl

dependencies.description: Provide the stuff missing in List::Util
dependencies.name: perl-list-moreutils

dependencies.description:
Module::Build is a system for building, testing, and installing Perl
modules. It is meant to be an alternative to ExtUtils::MakeMaker.
Developers may alter the behavior of the module through subclassing in a
much more straightforward way than with MakeMaker. It also does not
require a make on your system - most of the Module::Build code is pure-
perl and written in a very cross-platform way.
dependencies.name: perl-module-build

dependencies.description: Scalar::Util - A selection of general-utility scalar subroutines
dependencies.name: perl-scalar-list-utils

dependencies.description: Set::Scalar - basic set operations
dependencies.name: perl-set-scalar

dependencies.description: Perl extension for generating Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) documents.
dependencies.name: perl-svg

dependencies.description: Most commonly needed test functions and features.
dependencies.name: perl-test-most

dependencies.description: Easily test network connectivity
dependencies.name: perl-test-requiresinternet

dependencies.description: Uniform Resource Identifiers (absolute and relative)
dependencies.name: perl-uri

dependencies.description:
This module extends the XML::Parser module by Clark Cooper. The
XML::Parser module is built on top of XML::Parser::Expat, which is a
lower level interface to James Clark's expat library.
dependencies.name: perl-xml-dom

dependencies.description:
XML::DOM::XPath allows you to use XML::XPath methods to query a DOM.
This is often much easier than relying only on getElementsByTagName.
dependencies.name: perl-xml-dom-xpath

dependencies.description:
This module is an interface to libxml2, providing XML and HTML parsers
with DOM, SAX and XMLReader interfaces, a large subset of DOM Layer 3
interface and a XML::XPath-like interface to XPath API of libxml2. The
module is split into several packages which are not described in this
section; unless stated otherwise, you only need to use XML::LibXML; in
your programs.
dependencies.name: perl-xml-libxml

dependencies.description: XML::Parser - A perl module for parsing XML documents
dependencies.name: perl-xml-parser

dependencies.description:
XML::SAX is a SAX parser access API for Perl. It includes classes and
APIs required for implementing SAX drivers, along with a factory class
for returning any SAX parser installed on the user's system.
dependencies.name: perl-xml-sax

dependencies.description:
This module has a very simple task - to be a base class for PerlSAX
drivers and filters. It's default behaviour is to pass the input
directly to the output unchanged. It can be useful to use this module as
a base class so you don't have to, for example, implement the
characters() callback.
dependencies.name: perl-xml-sax-base

dependencies.description:
A new XML Writer was needed to match the SAX2 effort because quite
naturally no existing writer understood SAX2. My first intention had
been to start patching XML::Handler::YAWriter as it had previously been
my favourite writer in the SAX1 world.
dependencies.name: perl-xml-sax-writer

dependencies.description: An API for simple XML files
dependencies.name: perl-xml-simple

dependencies.description:
This module provides a way to process XML documents. It is build on top
of XML::Parser. The module offers a tree interface to the document,
while allowing you to output the parts of it that have been completely
processed. It allows minimal resource (CPU and memory) usage by building
the tree only for the parts of the documents that need actual
processing, through the use of the twig_roots and
twig_print_outside_roots options. The finish and finish_print methods
also help to increase performances. XML::Twig tries to make simple
things easy so it tries its best to takes care of a lot of the (usually)
annoying (but sometimes necessary) features that come with XML and
XML::Parser.
dependencies.name: perl-xml-twig

dependencies.description:
This module has been released to CPAN as YAML::Old, and soon YAML.pm
will be changed to just be a frontend interface module for all the
various Perl YAML implementation modules, including YAML::Old
dependencies.name: perl-yaml

dependent_to.description: An Automatic Functional Annotation and Classification Tool
dependent_to.name: autofact

dependent_to.description:
Guidance: Accurate detection of unreliable alignment regions accounting
for the uncertainty of multiple parameters.
dependent_to.name: guidance

dependent_to.description:
MAKER is a portable and easily configurable genome annotation pipeline.
It's purpose is to allow smaller eukaryotic and prokaryotic
genomeprojects to independently annotate their genomes and to create
genome databases. MAKER identifies repeats, aligns ESTs and proteins to
a genome, produces ab-initio gene predictions and automatically
synthesizes these data into gene annotations having evidence-based
quality values. MAKER is also easily trainable: outputs of preliminary
runs can be used to automatically retrain its gene prediction algorithm,
producing higher quality gene-models on subsequent runs. MAKER's inputs
are minimal and its ouputs can be directly loaded into a GMOD database.
They can also be viewed in the Apollo genome browser; this feature of
MAKER provides an easy means to annotate, view and edit individual
contigs and BACs without the overhead of a database. MAKER should prove
especially useful for emerging model organism projects with minimal
bioinformatics expertise and computer resources. Note: MAKER requires
registration. Fill out the form at
http://yandell.topaz.genetics.utah.edu/cgi-bin/maker_license.cgi to get
a download link. Spack will search your current directory for the
download file. Alternatively, add this file to a mirror so that Spack
can find it. For instructions on how to set up a mirror, see
https://spack.readthedocs.io/en/latest/mirrors.html
dependent_to.name: maker

dependent_to.description: Regular expression-based Perl Parser for NCBI Entrez Gene.
dependent_to.name: perl-bio-asn1-entrezgene

dependent_to.description:
Bio::DB::BigFile -- Low-level interface to BigWig & BigBed files for
perl
dependent_to.name: perl-bio-bigfile

dependent_to.description: Bio::DB::HTS - This is a Perl interface to the HTS Library.
dependent_to.name: perl-bio-db-hts

dependent_to.description: File parsing and writing code for Ensembl.
dependent_to.name: perl-bio-ensembl-io

dependent_to.description: The Ensembl Variation Perl API and SQL schema.
dependent_to.name: perl-bio-ensembl-variation

dependent_to.description: BioPerl low-level API for retrieving and storing data from NCBI eUtils
dependent_to.name: perl-bio-eutilities

dependent_to.description:
Prokka is a software tool to annotate bacterial, archaeal and viral
genomes quickly and produce standards-compliant output files.
dependent_to.name: prokka

dependent_to.description: Rapid large-scale prokaryote pan genome analysis
dependent_to.name: roary

dependent_to.description: Automatically optimise three of Velvet's assembly parameters.
dependent_to.name: velvetoptimiser

dependent_to.description:
Ensembl Variant Effect Predictor (VEP) determines the effect of your
variants (SNPs, insertions, deletions, CNVs or structural variants) on
genes, transcripts, and protein sequence, as well as regulatory regions.
(Requires addtional data available via the `vep-cache` package)
dependent_to.name: vep

description:
BioPerl is the product of a community effort to produce Perl code which
is useful in biology. Examples include Sequence objects, Alignment
objects and database searching objects. These objects not only do what
they are advertised to do in the documentation, but they also interact -
Alignment objects are made from the Sequence objects, Sequence objects
have access to Annotation and SeqFeature objects and databases, Blast
objects can be converted to Alignment objects, and so on. This means
that the objects provide a coordinated and extensible framework to do
computational biology. BioPerl development focuses on Perl classes, or
code that is used to create objects representing biological entities.
There are scripts provided in the scripts/ and examples/ directories but
scripts are not the main focus of the BioPerl developers. Of course, as
the objects do most of the hard work for you, all you have to do is
combine a number of objects together sensibly to make useful scripts.
The intent of the BioPerl development effort is to make reusable tools
that aid people in creating their own sites or job-specific
applications. The BioPerl website at https://bioperl.org/ also attempts
to maintain links and archives of standalone bio-related Perl tools that
are not affiliated or related to the core BioPerl effort. Check the site
for useful code ideas and contribute your own if possible.
name: perl-bioperl

variants.description: Build systems supported by the package
variants.name: build_system
